question: why is the cache not updated when a cache is found and the session key matches the cache value? The session expiry can be refreshed (See horizon/middleware/base.py for details). If so, I think the cache of user_pk here will be expired first. I might be wrong.

I am not sticking to a specific solution here.

Let me explain what is the problem.

My points are that if SESSION_REFRESH is True a session timeout will be extended in every access but the user cache introduced here is not refreshed.

Let's assume that SESSION_TIMEOUT is 1000s. User-A logs into horizon at time 0 and accesss again with a same session at time 500. The session expiration time will be extended to time 1500 (500+1000) [1]. The user cache timeout is still time 1000.
Thus, after time 1000, the session continues but the user cache will no longer exist.

If user-a logs in a new session at time 1300 (and the first session is not access after time 500), the user cache for user-a no longer exists, so the first session will not be deleted. Both of the first and second sessions will be active. I believe this is not what you want.

Hope the above explanation helps you find a solution.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/src/branch/master/horizon/middleware/base.py#L73-L78

specs/victoria/support-revert-any-snapsh.message:
We need more detail in the spec, this is what we discussed in the mid-cycle:

Some drivers cannot do it because if they do it they lose all other snapshots that were created after the middle snapshot we are reverting to.

For example if we have: snap1, snap2, and snap3 and we revert to snap1, then some drivers delete the actual data in snap2 and snap3.

So we need a new flag in the drivers so they can report that they don't lose data when reverting to middle snapshots.  The default for this flag should be that they lose data.

Then the code in cinder/volume/manager.py has to check if the revert is to a middle snapshot and the driver doesn't support it, and in that case the manager.py needs to do a generic revert, which consists of:

- Create temporary volume from snapshot
- Attach temporary volume and destination volume
- Copy data between the volumes
- Detach volumes
- Delete the temporary volume

That way we don't limit the snapshot we can revert to at the API level, and it will work for all drivers.

It will be a fast operation for some drivers, and slow for the others.

In addition to Rajat's point (that is, to make clear that you are proposing to change the revert-to-snapshot REST API to allow a volume to be reverted to *any* snapshot), you should also emphasize the second item mentioned in your use case, that is, what will happen to those snapshots more recent than the one reverted to.  (Gorka talks about the issues related to this in the next comment.)

I think you need to better explain what "otherwise limit" means here.

As the points mentioned in the previous patchsets touched on, we need consistent behavior from Cinder. So we either need to have an optimized path where the driver and backend can handle reverting to any snapshot, or we need a less optimal way to get the same end state without losing data or providing unexpected behavior from one cloud to another.

That last part is the tricky part, and why things were limited to just the last snapshot as it has been so far. This just isn't universal storage functionality, so it is hard to make it behave like it is through Cinder.
This spec should also state what the required change is in the API that will require a microversion. There are no details here about how the API changes with this.
Will also need to update the driver support matrix to list which drivers have optimized revert functionality.

The current 'revert' action is defined to take a snapshot_id, so the JSON request won't change at all.  So my question is, how do you see this working?  What I mean is:

- suppose that your microversion for this feature is 3.68
- suppose a user has volume v with snapshots s1, s2, s3 (where s3 is most recent)
- suppose the user makes the request POST /v3/{project_id}/volumes/{v}/action with request body

  {"revert": {"snapshot_id": s2}}

If the user passes the header "OpenStack-API-Version: volume 3.65", will this request fail?  In other words, does the user need to specify "OpenStack-API-Version: volume 3.68" in order to revert the volume to s2?

What's at issue here is whether the old behavior is desirable, that is, whether a user might *want* a revert-to-snapshot request to fail if they pass a middle shapshot in the request.  If that's desirable, then they can just use mv < 3.68 to get the behavior they want.

If you're not sure about this, that's OK, I won't hold up the spec over this.  (We can discuss it at a cinder meeting and update the spec later.)
I'm really not sure if it is controlled by version number.

Because this is controlled by a config option, it's going to be difficult for a user to tell whether this functionality is available or not.  I guess the best we can do is to modify the error message when mv 3.68 or later is requested and the config option is False to indicate that reverting to any snapshot is not supported in this cloud (if mv < 3.68 is requested, just use the current error message).

I guess this depends on how the config option behaves (see my question above).

One other impact is that the end user is somehow going to have to keep track of what's in their snapshots.  What I mean is this:

Suppose you have volume V, and you do the following:
monday: create snap s1
tuesday: create snap s2
wednesday: create snap s3
thursday: revert V to s1 and then create s4
friday, etc., continue working

When the user lists snapshots, most recent first, you get:
  s4, s3, s2, s1

But what you actually have is two chains:
  s1, s4
  s1, s2, s3

The current cinder model doesn't allow this, because to get back to s1, you would have to have deleted s2 and s3, so when you listed snapshots, all you would see is
  s4, s1

In other words, it just so happens that all the snapshot chains available for a particular volume can currently be revealed by listing the snapshots in chronological order.  But once your proposal is implemented, this will no longer be the case.  This is going make things difficult for users unless you have some scheme for adding appropriate info to the snapshots so that users can distinguish chains.  (This is the problem about shapshots forming a tree that Eric brought up a while back, but I don't think you ever addressed it.)

thanks for explain very much。
I thought about it. If we restore and creation snapshot frequently，the tree will be many，and difficult to manage in the cinder layer， i realy have no good idea about this，
I think above problem should managed by the storage system。

I tend to agree that this complexity should be managed by the storage backend, but the operator should also be aware of what has transpired on their volume. The timestamps should allow them to see the current date of the volume, as that should match the last snapshot restore that was performed - if it doesn't then it should, otherwise there is no way to track any snapshot recvoery has occured. Can someone check this (I can't currently as I don't have access to a system [due to time of year[) and confirm if the timestamp changes on the volume after a snapshot restore - this is the way a backend generally exposes that a snapshot recovery has occured.
It should be clearly stated in the user documentation that where there are multiple snapshots it is the responsibilty of the operator to manage the recovery actions that have previously been employed on a volume.

OK - I had a chance to check the revert-to-snapshot functionality and a revert does not change the created timestamp for the volume. 
Without this timestamp changing to match the timestamp of the reverted snapshot there is no way to check if a volume has ever been reverted to. 
This, IMHO, is a bug with the revert-to-snapshot implementation.
I see no way forward for this spec until this is resolved.
any

openstack/identity/v3/role_system_group_.message: nit: please drop here links (this is inherited from base class) and sort attributes alphabetically

The other classes have the links property in them (role_domain_group_assignment.py, role_domain_user_assignment.py, role_project_group_assignment.py, role_project_user_assignment.py). I don't see this defined in Resource class - so wanted to verify that this should actually be removed. If so, should it be removed from the other classes?

Right, I have expressed myself wrong. "links" is a meta attribute that is used inside the listing call. Nobody should ever _want_ to see it, since it only relevant in the context of single page (and as such useless outside it) and only serves SDK to be able to fetch next page. Generally we should drop it as attribute from all resources, but it must not be done in this change. Just drop it from your implementation.

There is not documented agreement about this atm and we can initiate some discussion, maybe.

Because our main target in upstream is RDO, our support policy basically should follow the one in RDO.

If we aim to make c9 tripleo job voting in Wallaby then we should officially support CentOS 9. This requires adding proper test coverage (unit tests and integration tests) for CentOS 9. Note because puppet openstack has stable/xean release, adding new support for stable/wallaby requires the same for stable/xena first. Considering the effort and the resources we need to add these support I currently hesitate to go for extending support coverage in these past branches.

Even if we do not support CentOS 9 officially, we can fix any issue with CentOS 9 in stable/wallaby and xena as long as the fix doesn't break CentOS 8.

This line is getting a bit long. It would be preferable to split it to multiple lines. This will also make it easier to link the added comment JENKINS-34885 with the specific extra ARG.

If you want the module to be reusable outside of OpenStack infra (and this should be the case, as infra is done with jenkins), whitelist is not a good idea. Or, at least you should be able to pass whitelist as class parameter, and not hardcode it. E.g. zuul allows setting arbitrary parameters through parameter-function in zuul.layout.

Personally I do not want to bother with whitelist, as our jenkins is not accessible from outside our firewall, and whitelist just would add extra maintenance burden.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
A patch with a conflict merged [1] so I just needed to rebase this patch

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/827734

Agreed that embedding the sys.executable in *generated* config is not what we want, but that's just a side-effect of how we generate our configs. For runtime, we actually *do* want sys.executable as the default and it's not "too early", it's just "wrong if you have generated the config with a weird value". So it'd be ideal if we had some way of overriding it for config generation, but I'm not sure that exists.

If we must have an invalid default for this parameter, then I guess we need a utility method for get_python_interpreter() which returns "CONF.wsgi.python_interpreter or sys.executable" but that's kinda unfortunate.

Either way, setting this to None helps nobody I think, as it will just break wsgi users until they set that to something which is a breaking config change for people with this already deployed.
This doesn't work, as shown by the job. We can't just pass None there, we have to either default it ourselves at runtime, or avoid passing the kwarg altogether.
recheck nova-ceph-multistore - failed during setup, tempest could not find a valid image

Ack, sorry it took a while for me to reload this context from swap:

In a real wsgi environment, our sys.executable is something like /usr/bin/uwsgi, which does not work for our usage. So we need to override that to something real. To make it not changed for regular environments, we used sys.executable as the default, but perhaps without the thinking that None would also trigger that in the lower layers. Re-reading the help text, it says exactly that :P

So given that, any people running wsgi now would have to have it overridden to something legit, and others would be taking the default, which will be the same as None after this change.

I agree with Brian here. it does get resolved correctly later if none and changing the default will also not break anyone who is already setting it to custom value. What it does 'though is lessen confusion on any situation where the configs are not generated in the same environment as the service is executed.

For runtime, we actually *are* getting sys.executable as the default if we make this None:

https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.concurrency/src/commit/95b9334cfab6849fbe47e2b118e5355af3675dba/oslo_concurrency/processutils.py#L332

So I still think we need to make this None-unless-you-have-a-good-reason-to-change-it.
I'm going to Ninja this in for RC1.
Thanks Dan, took a while to understand what was wrong with it, but you're indeed correct here.
Thanks, Dan.  Agree with the changes.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm not 100% sure I get the logic. I always thought that what we do is basically:
1) make sure the guest cannot change its disk
2) duplicate the disk
3) allow the guest to change the disk again

I don't see how can we further reduce the time the disk is frozen.

I will check with QEMU team to have their opinion about the logic and the potential inconsistency during the mirorring.
I will come back to you with the information.

Yeah, I'm having the same concern: we would then change the behaviour and some operators could be afraid by this. We need to think about how to have a way to help Pierre for his bug, but not by modifying the behaviour. Should we provide some new config option maybe ?

this does chnage the logic since the guest can write to the disk while it is mirroring meaning the abort may not be safe.

the freeze only happens after teh rebase job is complete in your change where as before it happened before the rebase startred.

without checking the beahvior of abourt i may revertr chnages that happened to the disk during the copy.

Yes, I don't change the logic. I moved only the freeze of the file system after the mirroring of the disk.

In my case, the disk is store locally on the compute node with a big size (200Go and more). The mirror takes minimum 30 minutes and today the freeze is executed before this mirror so the file system is frozen for too long time. The change reduces this time because the freeze is applied only before the end of mirroring and the unfreeze just after.

what we kind of need to do is do an inital copy wihtout quiesing. then quiese and copy just the deltas, then abort and unquiese

basically do the 200G copy but with partly stale data then use that as a base for the block rebase so that only the intermdiaty changes need to be copied when we have blocked io. that we we minimise the time the disks are locked.

im not really sure what the best way to do that is.

QEMU community replies to the question: https://lists.nongnu.org/archive/html/qemu-block/2022-01/msg00456.html

2 things in the reply:
- they agree with the proposal
- they propose an improvement to use another mechanism in QEMU "backup block job"

im not sure this change is safe i think we need someone with qemu knoladge to speak to the behavior of abort on a block rebase if data has been written to the intermidearte tempory image

gibi's request for a comment explaining why we freeze when we do has been adreesed.
i have also seen some of the email exchanges and converstation regrading why this is ok
to do with the qemu comunity.

overally i think this is ok as a backportable fix but i think we should also move to the new qemu/libvirt apis to do this in the futrue removing the current workaround we have.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
do we need to work around this anymore?

we might just want to follow https://wiki.libvirt.org/page/Live-disk-backup-with-active-blockcommit
i guess we can but we should likely rework this in the Zed release

Yeah, I was wondering the same.  The QEMU version being referred to is super old, 1.3.  And it doesn't specify the bug beyond "a bug".

More generally, we should be able to use blockCopy() where possible -- see the copy() helper in Nova's nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py

Also, I've moved and slightly modified that wiki page I wrote to here: https://libvirt.org/kbase/live_full_disk_backup.html
I agree with you about the subject. Do you think is possible to this improvement in the second step?

can_quiesce shoudl not actully be quiescing the image so the logs are not correct.

quiescing has not failed since you have not tried to quiesce.

so instead of doing a rebase and aborting it we woudl do a normal thin snapshot then make a copy of that
merge the snap shot into the orginal base image and merge teh copy of the snapshot into the copy of the base image created above.

the process of snapshot for me:
1. guest.freeze_filesystems()
2. dev.rebase(disk_delta, copy=True, reuse_ext=True, shallow=True) # Create a mirror of disk
3. while not dev.is_job_complete() #wait for the end of mirroring (the issue is here, the waiting time depend on the size of the disk and the IOPS)
4. dev.abort_job()
5. guest.thaw_filesystems()

so here you are moving the quiesce to after the rebase is complete and before the abort.
when we do the abort will that result in a revert fo the disk change or will the abort merge the content form the disk?

i would assume we did the quiese before the rebase intentionally to avoid data lose when we did the revert so im not suer this is safe to do.

The mirroring is completed so the result is both disks are the same. After the end of step 2 (dev.is_job_complete == True), the mirroring of write continue on both disk and it's stop with step 4 (dev.abort_job).
So between steps 2 et 4, the write is synced between both disks.

the abort stop the mirroring between the both disk (original + copy)

No data lost during the abort FMPOV

Thank you for the explanation. Based on this I agree with the proposed change. Could you please add this explanation to the code as comment? That would help the reader to understand why freezing the FS is enough to be done after the mirror is finished.

So after the dev.is_job_complete() is True the job is still continue copy new data that recently got stale?  I mean the following sequence of events:

1) dev.rebase
2) dev.is_job_complete == True
3) quiesce
4) dev.abort_job
5) unquiesce

What if the VM writes to its disk between #2 and #3? Is that change still copied to the mirror?
+1 for using unquiesce and quiesce instead of _set_quiesced

cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/s.message: instead of passing code_level can we fetch it from the self or stats, that will avoid changing the existing function definitions

We can fetch code_level from self but will face the issue in failover situation as self.code_level is not up-to-date.

So, we are fetching the code_level from self._state (from COMMONDRIVER) and passing it as parameter to get_npiv_wwpns(). With the current code, we can not fetch the data from self._state direct in the function get_npiv_wwpns() as the class is not inheriting COMMONDRIVER.

So, we can skip the extra parameter introduction with one of the following approach:
a. Use self.code_level but attachment will fail after failover 
b. Use self._state[c'code_level'] but make a few code-changes at CLASS level(we should inherit COMMON_DRIVER class to the current).

It would be quite reasonable to store this as a constant somewhere instead of writing it over and over.

I didnt store it as a constant because there are many code levels used through out the code where constants are not used instead directly the value is used.

If you see in the following operations the code levels are directly compared:
delete_volume() -> 7, 7, 0, 0
delete_snapshot() -> 7, 7, 0, 0
check_flashcopy_rate() -> 7, 8, 1, 0
change_vdisk_iogrp() -> 6, 4, 0, 0
is_system_topology_hyperswap() -> 7, 6, 0, 0
_extend_volume_op() -> 7, 7, 0, 0
migrate_volume()
retype_iogrp_property()
_delete_replication_grp()

Defining macros for each code level will result in changes to many operations and every time we have to go to the constant to check the value. Hence to maintain the code consistency i directly used the value of code level as it has been followed throughout the code.

Note that if _update() raises NotFound at line 207, we won't send the 'end' notification (we sent the 'start' at line 187).  Also, the authorization check is done in _update(), so it's also possible it will raise a 403, which will also mean we've sent a start but not an end notification.  Same thing goes for your status checks ... they are happening after the 'start' notification has been sent.

I suggest refactoring this function to call validate_update(), then get the volume right away, then do the auth check, then make sure you're going to allow the staus change; after that, send the start notification, complete your work, and then send the end notification.
Done

I think you are calling _update() too early here, we don't want to change the database until we're sure the request is completely OK.

I think you'll have to refactor _update() to remove the volume-get and auth code out of there.  There may not be enough left to keep it as a function, that's up to you.

I think what you need to do in this function is:

  # any exceptions raised will be handled at the wsgi level
  # validate the request body (will raise if the schema check fails)
  update = self.validate_update(req, body=body)
  # see if the volume is available (will raise if not found)
  context = req.environ['cinder.context']
  volume = objects.Volume.get_by_id(context, id)
  # see if the caller is authorized to do this (will raise if not)
  self.authorize(context, 'reset_status', target_obj=volume)

  # at this point, we still don't know if we're going to
  # reset the volume's state.  Need to check what the caller
  # is requesting first.
  if update.get('status') == 'available':
      attachments = (
          db.volume_attachment_get_all_by_volume_id(context, id))
      if attachments:
          msg = _("Cannot reset-state to available "
                  "because volume has attachments.")
          raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)
  elif update.get('status') == 'in-use':
      attachments = (
          db.volume_attachment_get_all_by_volume_id(context, id))
      if not attachments:
          msg = _("Cannot reset-state to in-use "
                  "because volume does not have any attachments.")
          raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

  # ok, we are ready to do some work!
  msg = "Updating %(resource)s '%(id)s' with '%(update)r'"
  LOG.debug(msg, {'resource': self.resource_name, 'id': id,
                  'update': update})
  self._notify_reset_status(context, id, 'reset_status.start')

  self._update(context, id, update)
  self._remove_worker(context, id)
  if update.get('attach_status') == 'detached':
      _clean_volume_attachment(context, id)

  self._notify_reset_status(context, id, 'reset_status.end')

I think that covers everything, but you will of course check to make sure I didn't forget something!

tacker/sol_refactored/controller/vnflcm_.message:
Does not need to check whether cpdId or cpConfig key in the request exists in the base HOT of vnfinstance?

In the case of Instantiation, the unmatch of request parameters and base HOT causes error because the parameter in base HOT must be replaced by request parameters.

On the other hand, according to DefaultUserData::change_ext_conn, when they do not exist in the HOT, no CP will be changed and it does not cause error.
The operator may not be aware of the erroneous operation.

Please let me hear your opinion.

What I meant was when there was an unmatch between the baseHOT and the request parameter.
When cpdId exists only in baseHOT, error occurs in instantiation, but does not occur in change_ext_conn.
When cpdId exists only in the request parameter, error does not occurs both  instantiation and change_ext_conn.

If Tacker returns errors for former case, the operator may be aware of the wrong cpdId.

However, my proposal is effective only when the wrong cpdId is specified instead of the required cpdId. Also, when both required cpdId and wrong cpdId are specified, my proposal causes an error.
Therefore, I withdraw the comment.

I think the situation of Instantiation is same as change_ext_conn.
In the case of Instantiation, if there is a cpdId which is not defined in VNFD, error does not occur under current implementation.
